Since the end of FY10, DOL's FOIA backlog has increased by 18.5%. We attribute this increase, in part, to the decision to use the Departmental tracking system as the sole source of data for FOIA reporting. As stated previously, DOL believes that use of the system has allowed the agency to identify requests that may not have been counted in last year's FOIA report. The Department also increased the number of FOIA requests processed from 17,625 in FY2010 to 18,129 in FY2011., 336030=02-19-09, 340157=08-16-10, 336808=05-04-11, 348276=07-08-11, 444178=Signed at Washington, D.C. this 31st day of January 2012., 340389=03-26-10, 336262=01-13-09, 347276=09-23-11, 4738=In FY 2010, DOL established the Office of Information Services (OIS), which is overseen by the Solicitor of Labor, the Department's Chief FOIA Officer. The OIS is the focal point for the coordination of FOIA program improvement efforts at DOL. OIS provides agency-wide oversight, leadership and guidance to ensure compliance with FOIA, particularly to increase the quality, and timeliness of FOIA responses; reduce the backlog of pending FOIA requests; and review the effectiveness of each agency's FOIA processes in order to benchmark best practices, and make recommendations for programmatic improvements. No. 98-78, 91 Stat. 319, 341634=05-11-10, 5537=One of the initiatives advanced by OIS is the consistent use of the Department's centralized FOIA tracking database, the Secretary's Information Management System for FOIA or "SIMS-FOIA." DOL component agencies have utilized SIMS-FOIA in their FOIA processing to an increasing degree in the years since the database's launch in FY 2006. The system assigns a unique SIMS-FOIA number to each logged request. As part of the logging process, users enter information describing the request and various processing milestones that are required in this report. In past years, DOL agency components have used both SIMS-FOIA and other manual or automated tracking methodologies in the preparation of the annual FOIA report. However, with this report, for the first time DOL is using SIMS-FOIA as the sole source of data for its FOIA reporting requirements. Because the agency is not relying on manual or other tracking systems, there are some discrepancies between the data in this report and in the data reported in FY 2010. This report incorporates footnotes and other explanatory information to reconcile those differences., 343341=02-11-11, 360082=01-13-09, 335450=09-23-09, 344344=06-15-11, 345696=10-26-10, textBeforeTable: 1.    Agency-specific acronyms or other terms. III.    Definitions of Terms and Acronyms Used in the Report     A FOIA request can be made for any agency record. This does not mean, however, that the Labor Department will disclose every record sought. There are statutory exemptions that authorize the withholding of certain information. In addition, the agency cannot comply with a FOIA request if there are no responsive records. Further, FOIA does not require agencies to do research for the requester, to analyze data, to answer questions, or to create records in order to respond to a FOIA request.     C.    Why some requests are not granted.     The agency's response time generally ranges from five to fifty days. Complex requests usually take more time.     B.    Agency response time.
